nit: The "-e" on L31 is necessary because $STEP_CONFIG might contain embedded escape sequences, notably '\n'. L28 and L29 don't contain any, so the -e could be eliminated.

Optionally, you could use an escape sequence and combine the lines:

  echo -e "noop_resource('package')\nnoop_resource('service')" | tee /etc/config.pp

or do it all in one go:

  echo -e "noop_resource('package')\nnoop_resource('service')\n${STEP_CONFIG}" \
  | tee /etc/config.pp

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_firewall/t.message:
These extra rules should just be added to the default set, following the existing naming pattern. This role implements the same functions as puppet firewall and uses the name with a leading integer, which is why rules are combined, sorted, then reversed.

If we are to use this pattern, I suggest we do it as a guard: add the special anti-lockout rule, apply `firewall_rules_sorted`, then remove the special anti-lockout rule. This way we're not keeping rules on machines which were not part of the expected input system.
it should only accept SSH connection for ansible to not being locked out upon disconnects. Allowing everything would raise a security issue if disconnect happens right after this task.

Nope, that wouldn't solve the issue, actually:
since we're using -I (insert) option without any index, we'll basically end with:
DROP --comment '999 drop all'
port 22 ACCEPT --comment 'ssh anti-lockout'

And (probably) hit that very same issue again.

Another possibility:
- push all of the INPUT rules in a dedicated chain (TRIPLEO_INPUT)
- in the INPUT, add the anti-lockout rule
- create TRIPLEO_INPUT, *add* the RETURN TRIPLEO_INPUTS in INPUT
- update the content of the TRIPLEO_INPUT (and therein, the '999 drop all')
- remove the anti-lockout rule from INPUT

That would be a deeper change though, and I'm not 100% sure bout the benefits - though, here, we may be able to ensure we only have our rules, and drop anything not known by tripleo itself... Maybe as a follow-up? We want to avoid that bug to hit more infra, so we may consider the current as a "quick work-around before a proper, nicer and safer fix".

WDYT?

> since we're using -I (insert) option without any index, we'll basically end with:

I don't think we actually need this anymore, but removing it is out of scope here.

<edit> OK, I think I've wrapped my head around what my beef with this PS is:

It's doing too many things at once (probably my fault, since I asked to move stuff to just a list of tasks in the pre playbook).

I think we need a patch under this one, that moves the roles in here as a list of tasks (and removes the roles entirely) and removes numactl since we don't need it anymore.

The reason for this is while the pre.yaml playbook is common to all whitebox jobs (we need the tempest SSH key everywhere, as well as crudini), the hugepages setup will only get used in the hugepages job.

In that second patch we can add the job as well, and the new test code, so everything gets tested at once and comes in as a unit.

What changed recently is that even the cloud admin user needs the role to be granted access.

> So user role assignment has been required since forever.

I'm not 100% sure on this part. Previously (w/ Ussuri mostly), tempest with a dynamic user provisioning just worked, but now with Wallaby at least, the following config or equivalent is required to run Octavia tests. So I suppose there have been some changes between Ussuri and Wallaby.

[tempest.conf]
> [auth]
> tempest_roles = load-balancer_admin

The functional tests impose this change from Wallaby onward: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/commit/13eb8006826e63a2e815305af31efca1422ebe89

So are we certain Victoria is the correct inflection point?
TBH I'm not quite sure when the requirement for the admin user to have the required load-balancer role came in - it may be adjunct to the admin or owner policy override addition to the source tree.

I went with Victoria based on:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-octavia/+bug/1961198/comments/7
Doing a bit of spelunking, I found that this change appears to have been added in in commit a5f142c566e5f5654b341c47c23a35b47e8983d1 which was included in Wallaby.

specs/zed/approved/owner-nova-trait-usag.message:
this does not actually describe the problem.
I would reword this as follows:

Today in placement each resource class is typically only used by a single service.
With the introduction of VGPU support in cyborg both nova and cyborg now share ownership
or usage of the VGPU resource class. This creates a usage problem where different
workflows are required to correctly consume the VGPU resource class based on which service created the inventory.

As both the nova and cyborg projects can report VGPU resources, we should be able to
solve the shared VGPU resource class problem by each service recording that they created or "own" the resource provider, however, that is not done today.
this is not part of the problem desciption its describing waht we coudl do if we implemented this so it shoudl not be in this section so this should just be remvoed.

so this is a use case but the rest of this section is not

I would personally replace it with these 3 use cases instead.

As an operator, I would like to be able to deploy multiple services that can share the same resource class name without creating scheduling conflicts.

As an operator, I want to have a way to transition management of resources between OpenStack service using simple operations such as resizing an instance from a flavor that consumes VGPUs provided by nova to a flavor that uses VGPUs provided by cyborg.

As an end-user, I would like to be able to consume resources from nova and cyborg in a single instance without having to understand the detail of placement or scheduling.
again this is implemation detail not part of the usecase so this should be deleted.

Nova will tag every ResourceProvider it creates with a OWNER_NOVA trait,
implying that inventories are provided by this service only.

Nova will provide a pre-filter that actively requests its own OWNER_NOVA trait
while cyborg will require the OWNER_CYBORG trait via its device profile to filter their own managed resources.

Content looks good. I just suggest a cleanup of the language:

We need to make sure that the nova VGPU feature still works during a rolling upgrade to the nova version introducing the OWNER_NOVA trait.

So to ensure that the nova compute service version will be bumped to signal when a compute service is upgraded and therefore reports the OWNER_NOVA trait on its RPs. The pre-filter filtering on OWNER_NOVA will only be enabled if the minimum compute service version indicates that every compute service is now upgraded and therefore reporting the OWNER_NOVA trait.

This way during a rolling upgrade with old compute still present the pre-filter will not be enabled and the nova VGPU feature will work as today. But as soon as all the computes are upgraded the pre-filter will automatically start enforcing the OWNER_NOVA trait for all the nova VGPU feature requests.

+1

the alternative here is to have a fallback query without the owner trait for upgrades but I prefer the automatic approach of the min compute service version check so yes please update this.

I would suggest the following:

To enable rolling upgrade a new compute service version will be introduced to indicate support for reporting owner traits. During an upgrade, the placement service must be upgraded before nova to ensure the new standard trait ``OWNER_NOVA`` is available. Then the nova controller services can be upgraded as normal. while the rolling upgrade is in progress a min compute service version check in the prefilter will prevent it from modifying the resource request until all compute services are upgraded. Once all compute services are upgraded the prefilter will be enabled for all new requests allowing resource classes to be shared between services.
that's what we agreed on the PTG.

can we ensure that after the change to ovn that a live migration will result in also migrating form hybrid_plug=true to hybrid_plug=false


this wont work on cold migration since that has only a single port bidnign so we cant update the toplogy for a cold migration but we can for live migration since we have two port bidings.

I didn't really test whole OVS->OVN migration with this patch but I manually added removed binding details to the existing ports and then tried to restart Vms and it worked fine.

This problem should be solved with this patch as in that way ports would be still plugged in hybrid way after e.g. reboot of vm so there will be always only one qvoXXX port in br-int (tapXXX will be in the linuxbridge qbrXXX). OVN will not care if it's tap or qvo in the br-int and all will work just as good as before migration.
This can be later "fixed" by doing e.g. live migration of the instances (excactly like we already advice users to do during change from iptables_hybrid to ovs fw driver in ML2/OVS case).
recheck

yep however before we merge this we need to ensure that they hybrid plug flag does not change wehn we do cold migrate or it may break subsequent hard reboots.

basically if the binding detail are updated to set hybrid_plug=false
when we update the binding:host-id to the destiation host that happens after
we have gerated the xml for the destion host so the vm will be created with the
hybrid bridge.

if nova network info cache is then updated with this info the next hard reboot will try to clean up as if we had booted with hybrid_plug=false and it will leak the bridge as it will jsut try to remove the ovs port.

so we need to ensure that we have tested that before we merge this as the only time we can change this is wehn creating a prot bidnign for the rist tiem like when we create an inactive port binding for the destion host using the multiple port bidnigs workflow used for live migrtation.

that process happen before the xml is generated and allow  nova ot clean up the source node properly as it has both sets of data.

we could perhaps close this gap in os-vif and have it check if there are bidges to clean up but by default i expect this not to work properly for cold migration so we shoudl ensure it does not change on the neutron side.

perhaps we could use the presence of migrating too or the fact that there is only one port bindign to detect this?

in any case i think it would be good to at least test that config.
can we do that with fullstack or tempest?

Tempest support all active openstack releases.
As soon as a release moves to Extended Maintenance state, the QA team is allowed to changed tempest in an incompatible way with the older release. It doesn't mean it happen immediately (train moved to EM some time ago), but for example train still supports python 2 and newer tempest is less likely to work properly with it. Anyway, a train-last was created in tempest and all plugins, which means it's time to use it.
See also: 
https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_support_policy.html

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I tested this change on recent tripleo-current undercloud and it fixes the issue previously seen when deleting introspection rules.
I think this is an appropriate defensive solution for a particular server environment behavior, even though that behavior only shows on an older python stack.

Julia and I have found an issue in eventlet that may explain this bug. TL;DR eventlet sends `Transfer-Encoding: chunked` for empty responses, including for HTTP 204 where it's forbidden by https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc7230.html#header.transfer-encoding.

ironic_inspector_client/common/http.py.message:
So basically we have a blend of components and things doing evil things.

And by evil, I mean everything with the best of intentions, the issue, in part, is the way this operates together.

- We reply with empty bodies, with the appropriate code. In the API that is. Well, Null bodies which can't be read as json, but hey is still valid http wise.

- The WSGI/App/Interface is converting responses to be marked with chunked encoding. Because surely everything *must* have a response body. (unless it is a redirect...)

- The client, upon seeing it thinks "Oh, there surely must be a body, lets iterate over it because of what WSGI injects says "There is a body here!" But in reality, there is no body.

I believe Harold has commented that he tried in forcing a content length parameter to be injected into the response which would be the most appropriate thing for these bodies for the client, but yeah. No dice.

So moving to stream, *does* change request reading/iteration behavior. It does navigate away from the issue we're seeing as the intermediate entries *are* trying to load the response body.  I've got the patch I did to fix the server side complaints Apache was making a while back, so going through each request and flaging them as they would be streamed and gets us out of the land where requests is trying to populate a content body object.

Ultimately, I think we should change the API to just include a body. Technically breaking but I don't think it would be noticed at all and it is clear everything is expecting bodies on responses at this point even things which traditionally are no content responses.

manila_tempest_tests/tests/scenario/mana.message: shouldn't this happen in the super class's create_server method as well? https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/914b096dfd6b829ea963d537aaa1db6c12bd28f2/tempest/scenario/manager.py#L252
+1, same I commented in other patches also like https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/barbican-tempest-plugin/+/830121/13/barbican_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/manager.py#89

I don't know about that. The logic behind this condition is as follows: 

Manila explicitly assigned 'namestart' to 'create_port_body', tempest doesn't do such thing. The condition was created to achieve logical equivalence of manila's and tempest's create_server method. 

create_port_body dict must be used only when CONF.network.port_vnic_type is present, otherwise the dictionary wouldn't be popped from kwargs (https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/914b096dfd6b829ea963d537aaa1db6c12bd28f2/tempest/scenario/manager.py#L249) and will cause failure later - https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/914b096dfd6b829ea963d537aaa1db6c12bd28f2/tempest/scenario/manager.py#L309, because compute.create_test_server doesn't accept such kwarg.

its not just the manila tests -- the code existed in tempest at some point and got ported over to the plugins: https://codesearch.opendev.org/?q=%27namestart%27%3A%20%27port-smoke%27&i=nope&literal=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=

This commit in tempest removed it: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/512234/3/tempest/scenario/manager.py


So, i don't mind us dropping it here too, so the next person doesn't wonder why we're customizing the port namestart... what do you think?

Firstly, I agree with you that a detailed report with clear problem description is needed here.

That said, Dave can you try this targeted skip, instead of skipping the whole of _check_cpu_compatibility():

  try:
      if not CONF.workarounds.disable_cpu_type_validation:
          self._compare_cpu(cpu, self._get_cpu_info(), None)


The reason the above is more sensible is because current MIN version of libvirt (that Nova relies on) already _does_ do this compatibility-check. So this compatibility check is bogus in some cases.

The solution to some of these CPU compat bugs here is either we switch to the new APIs, which is work in progress[1], or more crudely to disable the _compare_cpu() check — which was needed in the past, but not now anymore.

this change makes the lock_path a required config option whereas previously because we were using internal locks it was optional.

that means that nova unit tests will start to fail if this is released

before this change, the use of an internal lock meant that the lock_path was not required and nova did not have to mock or set the environment variable. with the change to using external locking that is not required.  that requirement is called out in the release notes but as a result of this new requirement, this patch is not safely back portable. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-brick/+/817708/4/releasenotes/notes/external-locks-9f015988ebdc37d6.yaml#2

if we wanted to backport this without break nova or real deployments where this is not set we would have to provide a real default. 

I'm not sure we want to revert this at this point but this was not in line with sable policy as it required config changes and this may cause issues when we go to make another release of os-brick for stable branches.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I understand how this addresses a bug introduced by afe3b76e6f55d96 [aptly_deb_usage: Remove file folders before upload packages] but it doesn't describe how the issue that change was attempted to fix is not impacted. Are we just doing circles here?

HaHa, it is not a circle. :-)
The purpose of the previous commit is to fix a bug that a binary package of deb-local-build been placed in deb-local-binary. Before that commit, all repositories share one upload file directory. Suppose we just upload a binary package of deb-local-build, before we insert it into the repository the process been interrupted. That very package file will leave in the upload file directory by thin interruption. Next time when we upload a package into deb-local-binary, this package will also be inserted into deb-local-binary. Commit afe3b76e6f55d96 use different file directory for different repository. Thus deb-local-binary use a file directory called "deb-local-binary", while deb-local-build use a file directory called "deb-local-build". This can avoid package been inserted into wrong repository. Another modification of that very commit is remove all file directories each time before we upload files to avoid old package file left in it. The purpose of this modification is to make the package-upload more clean. Even the package of this very repository, if the process been interrupted, it will be abandon. While as I said in this commit, this operation is not fit for source package that contains several files. So revert this very part to make it.
With this commit, still, packages of repo-A will not been placed into repo-B.

Remade the code to test the path actually passes to RunneConfig.

The point is to ensure that the run method works with path correctly, and doesn't mangle it.

The asserts work in following fashion:
1. We verify that open was called only once, and exactly once. 
   Otherwise, our assumptions about how the method works are broken, 
   and rest of the test won't work.
2. If the path got mangled, passed incorrectly or is otherwise invalid,
   the run method has no way to recover, or to even notice. Until the path is used. 
   Then it would fail, potentially far from the place where the issue started. 
   The lstat function raises FileNotFoundError if, 
   and only if, the path points to nonexistent target, in an existing directory.
   Since the path we use points to nonexistent targe, but inside existing dir (/tmp),
   we get FileNotFoundError. 
   That way we verify that path is in valid format for our filesystem.
3. Finally we check that the path we want was actually passed to the open function.
   If we didn't first check that the open function was called once,
   we would have multiple call_args. Checking all of them, while verifying the order of calls,
   would be even more confusing. This way we only have a single call. 
   Using, as already discussed, valid path. All we need to do is check if the strings match.

jenkins_jobs/modules/builders.py.message:
Hi Eric, first of all, thanks for your contribution!

Since this is a common pattern I'd suggest adding a "shortcut" in 'registry' (ModuleRegistry), something like:

  def get_plugin_version(self, plugin_name):
    info = self.get_plugin_info(plugin_name)
    safe_version = info.get("version", str(sys.maxsize)).replace("-", "+")
    return pkg_resources.parse_version(safe_version)

Then you could simply replace the above 4 lines with just:

    version = registry.get_plugin_version("CMake plugin")

This would greatly simplify the code all over the place.

On the other hand I just found an existing code in JJB which does some version string parsing and manipulation: https://opendev.org/jjb/jenkins-job-builder/src/branch/master/jenkins_jobs/registry.py#L71

So it would be good to move your '-' -> '+' replacement there.

Finally please implement some tests to show it works as expected.

Thanks for your feedback Adam! Fixing this in registry.py is much cleaner. I added tests, and in the testing, I found that not ALL versions with hyphens become LegacyVersions (e.g. "1.0.1-1" is a Version, but "1.0.1-1.2" is a LegacyVersion). So I'm now testing to see if the version returned is LegacyVersion, and only then changing the '-' to '+'.

jenkins_jobs/registry.py.message: OK, so maybe after replacing the hyphen, we should do a final check to see if the version string is still parsed into a LegacyVersion and at least report a warning in the log? This should help identifying similar issues in the future.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Do you mind elaborating this ? As far as I've searched, I could not find any service overriding default logging_context_format_string.
So updated default in oslo.context is "propageted" to each services.

also note, that if some service changes its custom formatter context string or if default value in oslo changes, that change would have to be reflected over each of the aforementioned customizations. While with this change, users would have to change nothing, the keys will be smart added from the context dictionaries of services

With this change, the modification process would be for each service:

1) set logging_context_add_from=[context_key_foo, bar]
2) do not care about merging those with anything of the default formatters in oslo
3) do not care about merging those with anything of the (possibly) overriden formatters in service configs via the service code changes or external config managment systems
4) ??? (send SIGHUP)
5) PROFIT (see the change applied)

Without this patch the process is:
1) set logging_context_format_string to (if it is still actual by now?)
%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d %(levelname)s '
'%(name)s [%(request_id)s %(context_key_foo)s %(bar)s %(user_identity)s] '
'%(instance)s%(message)s'
2) make sure that doesn't change the oslo defaults, if changed
3) make sure that doesn't change the service code defaults, if it overrides it
4) make sure that doesn't change external config management systems customizations
5) send sighup, see the change applied

... 
repeat for each service

Hmm... if my observation is correct, at this moment no service actually overrides default value. I could not yet find any actual example that additional effort is required, and default change is "propagated" to the all services, unless user intentionally set the parameter by themselves.

The global_request_id feature is global, updating the root default would make sense.

Even if we add this parameter we need to set this parameter likely in every services. I don't see quite much more benefit than setting logging_context_format_string in every service while the current parameter is quite tricky and too much intentional to inject global request id despite of the naming which sounds like global user (I'd need to discuss this with Herve)

...or at least without bringing all the whole "%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [%(request_id)s %(user_identity)s] %(instance)s%(message)s" thing for each service config, but added the extra context keys.

If you look by https://codesearch.opendev.org/?q=logging_context_format_string&i=nope&literal=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=
you'll find out that each openstack service defaults that to its preferred choise. So there is no good and flexible way for operators to add extra formatter keys from the context data for all services at once, without going and overriding the whole logging_context_format_string for each service.

Even if you use this additinal parameter you need to care about consistency with the latest default of logging_context_format_string.
In case the default is updated and global_request_id is added then you need to update your own string to avoid duplicate global_request_id.
... and you also need to care about your own logging_context_format_string when you add this new parameter.

FWIW, this limits the control over changing formatters to the context placed into [] section. There could be follow-up to refactor the context formatter to be built fully dynamically, including request_id user_id etc. Like by placing those to the new default value of this new parameter.

oslo_log/_options.py.message:
Well, I think oslo.log should stay agnostic to data shared by services. So Instead of hard coding the `global_request_id` notion here, why not simply adding a new option that could accept a list of arguments where we can pass by example `global_request_id` and then retrieve it from the record dict and then log it.

That would allow us to also print other data without modifying oslo log each 2 minutes.

An other alternative could be by example to define this option and initiate it with a list of default values to log that could contains the `global_request_id`. The lib will remains more agnostic than with an hard coded parameter and will share a global context with all the services through these default values that could be overriden.

Thoughts?

That makes sense, although there oslo.log looks already global_request_id aware today. Also, the context-or-not logging formatter selection is already there, this change only extends it. I think what you describe is already there - the context string formatter. I don't think there is a need in another one, if users know, what and there to log, they should use that formatter string. It is unlikely that those "what and where" would be generic for all services though. Rather it would be runed in each searvice config. So, no, I don't think we need to bring it here, in oslo.log. Knowing this particular case, global_request_id, is common for all services and is enough to be covered here like this.
I think I got that you mean
The latest version of these changes looks sensible. LGTM
IMHO this parameter name is really confusing. This actually inject some context after global id while the parameter name indicates this affects the whole context information.

I'd like to request Herve to revisit this. The current logic of this is quite specific to request id as it injects additonal field just after request id.

So IMO this parameter should have more specific name, like logging_extra_request_identity_format.

'from' indicates to add given keys FROM the context dict
I couldn't think of a better naming, sorry

>  This actually inject some context after global id 

Let me fix some typos and rephrase this to clarify my point.

This actually inject some context elements after request id. The parameter name sounds like this appends something to the whole context storing.


In addition, for me it's not clear what "from" indicates here.

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-.message: For a 500GB disk this will result in /var growing by 426GB, and /srv by 47GB

honestly, in the past limiting the size of specific mountpoints has caused me more troubles than benefits ... do we have specific guidelines we're following in this scenario ?

not sure why isolate/limit /var/log and /var/log/audit vs /var ?

would it make sense to take a different approach use predictable (absolute) sizes leaving free space in the vg for people to grow their volumes as needed, when needed?

I have no historical knowledge of how much space a "typical" (if there is such a thing) swift service running on a Controller needs in a production environment. I'm hoping Christian has some insights.

How feasible would it be to tie the /srv size to a THT parameter? The docs could guide users on the need to choose a suitable size if they are using swift, in which case we trust they will know how much space to set aside. The default THT parameter value would reserve just enough space to handle CI's needs, but not set aside a large amount of space in case swift is not deployed (e.g. it's a ceph deployment).

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-.message:
The other aspect to consider is maybe we shouldn't consume the entire disk?

I guess my perception on Swift usage is that it is less with TripleO derived IaaS usage, but I have no definitive source of data without individual products having their own user surveys. Maybe this is something in terms of integration data which should be sought to better guide discussions such as this.

Overall, I think the proposal makes sense, my only worry is noted below in my next comment which also applies to this configuration block as well.

> How feasible would it be to tie the /srv size to a THT parameter? The docs could guide users on the need to choose a suitable size if they are using swift, in which case we trust they will know how much space to set aside. The default THT parameter value would reserve just enough space to handle CI's needs, but not set aside a large amount of space in case swift is not deployed (e.g. it's a ceph deployment).

The provision step has no knowledge of THT parameters, or of specific services installed in a role. But a THT parameter would have the same problem of the default not meeting all needs. Either way the docs need to guide the deployer to consider actual storage needs. The decision is also related to the size of the physical disk so I think its reasonable to be set at the baremetal provisioning step.

> honestly, in the past limiting the size of specific mountpoints has caused me more troubles than benefits ... do we have specific guidelines we're following in this scenario ?
> not sure why isolate/limit /var/log and /var/log/audit vs /var ?

This particular disk layout was part of Yolanda's original hardened image work [1] and the only modification since has been adding /srv to ensure swift data doesn't co-mingle with base OS root partition.

[1] http://teknoarticles.blogspot.com/2017/07/build-and-use-security-hardened-images.html

> would it make sense to take a different approach use predictable (absolute) sizes leaving free space in the vg for people to grow their volumes as needed, when needed?

That would be interesting, like a cron job which keeps growing volumes when they reach a capacity threshold? At this point it would be a significant amount of work to implement, and there would have to be controls in place to limit unmanaged file growth from claiming the whole disk (like an unrotated log file)

I'd really like to focus this review on actual values for /var and /srv though. My hunch is that a typical deployment would be an edge deployment where swift is used only for image storage, and the only images are a handful of generic base images that are generally only used to install openshift, so 47GB of a 500GB disk is appropriate.

I have no idea of the /var storage requirements for the ObjectStorage role. The image comes with a 0.9GB /var, with 0.2GB consumed, leaving ~0.7GB. Maybe this is enough for ObjectStorage and /srv should be grown by 100% in this case?
Yeah, setting aside 10% for var seems safer given the tendency for services to put stuff there.

More tests are always good, but this particular bug is at least already reproducible with the existing functional tests. We just haven't gotten the ovs 2.17.0 release yet to break everything. (I'm specifically holding off releasing it until this is all fixed). With the patch, the mech_driver tests pass for me.

Once we have a new ovsdbapp release, it might be good to see if we can pin python-ovs to a git checkout to verify nothing breaks horribly before I do the new python-ovs release.

Will do with ovs>=2.17.0. ovsdbapp version doesn't really matter for this method , it's just that ovsdbapp's update_tables() is also busted and we use that elsewhere in neutron.
I think we should test the behavior of this method by unit tests.

There are 3 cases:
< 2.17.0: No ConditionState, can't use cond_change(), setting/reading condition directly not officially supported
= 2.17.[01]: ConditionState, must use cond_change(), setting/reading condition directly not officially supported
> 2.17.1: ConditionState, can assign/read table.condition or use cond_change(), setting/reading condition directly officially supported.

So there's going to be a very small window where this code is going to be needed at all. And the PyPI release of 2.17.0 may actually have the fix since it hasn't been released yet. (distros will not).

But basically, there being a ConditionState attribute won't universally mean we *should* call cond_change(), just that we *can*. So I don't want to enshrine in a unit test that this exact behavior is maintained, because if it is modified at some point to just do table.condition = condition, that'd be fine. I'm still thinking about how to write a test that I don't hate, but I also can't imagine this method *ever* changing other than to be deleted. And if it was, I'd prefer to find a way to write a test that doesn't just have to change with it.

This brings up another issue, RAFT support in python-ovs is 2.17+. We have code to support non-leaderonly connections, but if someone uses RAFT with ovs <= 2.17 (or a distro with the backported RAFT support), every time it does a snapshot it will transfer leaders and break connections--which will not be fast reconnects, but instead full db dumps. So, when should we bump the requirement to 2.17+ (it's very new)? If it was soon, then requiring 2.17.2 would also make this code go away.
